results.title: Garde a Vue = the Grilling
results.creator_credit: Claude Miller, George Dancigers, Alexandre Mnouchkine, TF1 Films productions and Films Ariane
results.brief_description:
On New Year’s Eve, Inspector Antoine Gallien, assisted by Belmont are questioning local attorney Martinaud in regard to the rape and murder of two young girls whose bodies have been found on the beach. Martinaud knew one of the children. At first the questioning progresses politely, and then less so, as the interrogation team chips away at the suspect’s alibi and Martinaud becomes the prime suspect. Claude Miller’s film appears as a discreet homage to H.G. Clouzot’s ‘Quai des Orfevres’. Both films share the New Year’s Eve setting and the same names for the police inspectors. Awards: Prix Melies 1981 ; Grand Prix du Cinema Francais 1981 ; Montreal Film Festival - Best Scenario.

Credits: Producers, Alexandre Mnouchkine, Georges Dancigers ; director, Claude Miller ; writers, Michel Audiard, Jean Herman, Claude Miller ; photography, Bruno Nuytten ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Lino Ventura, Michel Serrault, Romy Schneider, Guy Marchand, Elsa Lunghini, Jean-Claude Penchenat, Pierre Maguelon, Mathieu Schiffman, Michel Such, Patrick Depeyrat.

results.title: Garbo
results.creator_credit: Ron Cobb, Hugh Rule, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Eclectic Films
results.brief_description: There’s a garbage war going on between private contractors with swish automated machines and local council workers - the automated vehicles cut out the work of the middleman who collects the bin manually. Two such middlemen are Steve and Neill, dedicated waste disposal workers on the garbage truck named “Garbo”. The comraderie of council garbage collectors is evident as the automated Sanicleanse workers have the support of police, who turn a blind eye to such shenanigans as the theft of Christmas presents left out by thoughtful clients. Plot twists include the theft of the truck and a seaside holiday with the shrewish, overbearing, agoraphobic Freda after Steve mishears a woman he helps out at work talking on the phone inviting her friend on a holiday. This love interest proves to be the local copper’s daughter and to complicate matters Steve hasn’t been honest about his profession. Written by Stephen Kearney and Neill Gladwin (Los Trios Ringbarkus), “Garbo” is an amusing if inconsequential lightweight comedy. Cast also includes: Max Cullen, Simon Chilvers, Gerard Kennedy, Moya O’Sullivan, Imogen Annesley, Michael Veitch, John Brumpton.

results.title: Gannets of Bonaventure Island
results.creator_credit: Dan Gibson, Sidney Goldsmith and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film takes us to Bonaventure Island off the coast of Quebec, to visit a gannet colony. The social life, nesting, laying, incubation and flying of the gannets is shown.

results.title: Ganja & Hess = Ganja and Hess
results.creator_credit: Bill Gunn, Chris Schultz and Kelly-Jordan Enterprises
results.brief_description: This surprisingly contemplative work from African-American director Bill Gunn was released as a black vampire film after heavy editing and studio interference saw its melancholic soundtrack removed and run-time reduced to 83 minutes. Despite being commissioned to make a generic horror movie, Gunn (who also stars as George Meda) created a work of singular originality, subverting the tropes of the genre in favour of a challenging work that addresses issues of African-American culture and spirituality. Dr Hess Green, an esteemed anthropologist, is assigned a new assistant of unstable disposition, George Meda. When Hess is stabbed with an African relic, he becomes obsessed with blood, being possessed by an ancient curse. Hess infects his wife, Ganja, granting them both eternal life. With an elliptical structure the film is imbued with a dreamlike quality that is frequently menacing but never predictable. This blaxploitation work is considered iconic by many modern American filmmakers, including Spike Lee. At 110 minutes, this version is the restored director’s cut. Cast includes Marlene Clark and Duane Jones. Also known as Double Possession, Blood Couple, and Black Vampire.

results.title: Gangster no. 1
results.creator_credit: Paul McGuigan, Jonathan Cavendish, Norma Heyman, Pagoda Productions and FilmFour
results.brief_description: Told mainly in flashback, “Gangster No.1” chronicles the bloody rise and unceremonious fall of the oddly named Gangster 55 (Malcolm McDowell/Paul Bettany). Director Paul McGuigan’s violent fable follows the young Gangster’s initiation into London’s glamourous crime scene of the sixties, after he is hand picked by the suave and sinister crime boss Freddie Mays (David Thewlis). Gangster’s violent disposition quickly escalates him to the inner circle of Freddie’s crime syndicate, while the impressionable Gangster begins to develop a strong infatuation for Freddie and his opulent lifestyle. The obsession takes a dangerous turn however when Freddie meets night club singer Karen (Saffron Burrows), leaving the jealous Gangster fuming and thirsty for revenge. McGuigan’s flashy visual style fetishizes this motley crew of gangsters, at times filming them in slow motion, bathing them in lush colours and filtering their violence through fractured lenses. Cast includes Kenneth Cranham, Jamie Foreman and Eddie Marsan.

results.title: Gangs of New York
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Harvey Weinstein, Alberto Grimaldi, Australian National Football Council and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: With “Gangs of New York” Martin Scorsese (Casino, Goodfellas, Taxi Driver, The Last temptation of Christ) produced his most mainstream and commercially ambitious film to date. “Gangs” tells the story of New York as it was in the mid-19th century - a violent and untamed arena of gangs, immigrants, crooks and crime. Anchoring the narrative is Bill the Butcher (Daniel Day-Lewis) a ruthless American-born gang ruler with a merciless nature who delights in taunting immigrants. In an almighty showdown (with an array of killing apparatus used in hand-to-hand combat) Bill kills the honourable Irish Priest Vallon. Years later Vallon’s young son, Amsterdam, who witnesses the murder, seeks vengeance, even as he forms a bond with the charismatic Bill. A part of Amsterdam’s journey sees him romancing the free-spirited pickpocket Jenny (Cameron Diaz) and leading his own honourable ‘gang’, amid a climate of sanctioned corruption and overt racism. Scorsese’s eighteenth feature divided the critics in terms of its merit. Indeed some elements of the film, principally the romance between Jenny and Amsterdam (arguably added to entice a youth audience), don’t quite gel and reputed clashes between Scorsese and Miramax boss (and producer) Harvey Weinstein may account for the film’s uneven tenor. What does impress however is the scale of the sets, the epic historical tone and the extraordinary central performance by Daniel Day Lewis. Nominated for ten (winning zero) Academy Awards.

results.title: Gangs
results.brief_description:
A short created by a student for the 2004 ACMI Diegesis secondary school media festival.
This animated work relates the story of a young naive boy’s horrific beating by a vicious student from his school. The young boy calls his older brother - a member of a gang, to avenge his beating. The older brother gathers up his friends and visits the student at his school and beats him in the school toilets. The vicious student retaliates by murdering the young boy. A bleak story of revenge.

results.title: Gang related
results.creator_credit: Jim Kouf, John Bertolli, Steve Stabler, Brad Krevoy and Orion Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Notorious for being rapper turned actor Tupac Shakur’s final film appearance before being gunned down in 1996, ‘Gang related’ is a tense crime drama about corruption, gangs and drugs. Detectives Divinci (James Belushi) and Rodriguez (Tupac Shakur) are two bent street detectives with a flourishing byline drug scam which involves Divinci’s girlfriend, Cynthia (Lela Rochon) as bait. The partners have vastly different motivations behind their actions - Divinci wants to retire while Rodriguez has a gambling debt to repay. Both are united by their belief that the men they kill deserve it. Their plan quickly unravels when one of the punters turns out to be an undercover D.E.A. and they are not able to wash their hands as cleanly for the murder with their usual “gang-related” dismissal. Cast also includes James Earl Jones, David Paymer and Wendy Crewson. Includes bonus footage including the last ever interview with Tupac Shakur.

results.title: Gandhi and the end of an Empire
results.creator_credit: Gilles Delannoy, Gaumont-British Instructional and Vision 7
results.brief_description: An informative documentary about Mahatma Gandhi and the important role he played in India’s passage towards independence from British rule. Discusses Gandhi’s life, his beliefs and his aspirations for a united India where Hindus and Muslims live in peace and harmony and where his theories of non-violence and non-cooperation will lead to autonomy and independence. Also provides an indepth look at India’s history from the turn of the century through to Gandhi’s assassination in 1948 discussing the tenets of the Hindu religion; the diversity that exists within India in relation to language, culture and religion; the caste system; the strategies devised by Gandhi to break Britain’s control of India; the violence and bloodshed associated with the independence movement and these divisions; the appointment of Jawaharlal Nehru as leader of the Indian Congress Party; the formation of Pakistan; Britain’s withdrawal from India; India’s independence. Uses archival film footage, stills and newsreels. Narrated by Michel Pascal. Teacher Notes are included. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
